primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God (Subject) saves and transforms the believer (Object/Receiver) through the perfect patience of Christ, enabling the believer to endure suffering and love others.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus Christ, through his perfect patience, atoned for our impatience
The Lord is full of compassion and mercy
Jesus Christ saving you through his infinite patience
the Father can be endlessly patient with us
God is God... He is worthy of my trust
The Judge is standing at the door
so that the Father can be endlessly patient with us

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit / The Cross / The Word
tekstueel_bewijs: look at the ultimate Job... the cross

tegenstander.identificatie: The Human Heart / Sin / Forces of Darkness
tekstueel_bewijs: Your heart is not on your side
all the forces of darkness, evil, and hell were coming down on him
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but a heart naturally inclined toward 'the hell of eternal autobiography' and cosmic evil that only Christ could withstand.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer (Subject) practices patience toward others and circumstances (Object) as a response to grace.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is explicitly fueled by the primary program (soteriology). The believer acts because Christ first acted.

voorbeelden_god_subject: Jesus Christ atoned for our impatience.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We live in a culture that doesn’t value patience.

voorbeelden: You must also think of the past.
I want you to see three hints.
If you want to have a happy life.

that will make you into someone who can be patient.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon moves from Devoir (the command) to Savoir (explanation) but lands heavily on Pouvoir (the empowerment through Christ's work).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Starts at ~S1 (Impatience), moves to S2 (The Judge at the door), then reveals ~S2 (Mercy/Atonement) to lead the hearer to S1 (Patience).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ takes the S2 (Judgment) for our ~S1 (Impatience), granting us S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The 'Judge at the door' and the 'machine of the grumble' are treated as real ontological threats.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon contains many imperatives, they are structurally grounded in the indicative of Christ's 'perfect patience' as the 'True Job'.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Patience is the character trait we’re going to look at tonight.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus Christ, through his perfect patience, atoned for our impatience.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Prophets and Job are used as models, but immediately transcended by Christ.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Christ is the 'Ultimate Job' who does what Job could not.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and empowerment rather than burden.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon successfully links the 'Fruit of the Spirit' (Ethics) to the 'Cross' (Soteriology).
spanning_punten: The tension between 'You must be patient' and 'Your heart is not on your side'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus Christ... atoned for our impatience, so that the Father can be endlessly patient with us.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; sin is an 'eternal machine' that destroys the self.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is Christocentric. The Subject of the 'heavy lifting' is always Christ.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the current landing on Pouvoir.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Connect the 'New Yorker' examples more directly to the 'Cross' earlier.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in moving from a moral imperative to a grace-based indicative.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'New York' anecdotes, Greimas reveals these are 'Opponents' to the 'Object' of patience.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains James 5; semiotics explains how the sermon makes Christ the Subject of James 5.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'Subject' of the sermon's action is not the 'Patient Person' but the 'Patient Savior'.

volledige_subject_lijst: The Heart (is not on your side)
appendices.notities: The sermon uses 'Self-Trust' as the primary Opponent to 'Patience'.
